subhead: The Ministry of Education in Ramallah has set up an online exam for high school students in the coastal enclave. According to the United Nations, 97% of Gaza's schools have been destroyed or damaged by Israeli air strikes.

title: Jerome Powell, the US economy's compass
subhead: Under attack from Trump, Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve head, has held firm to preserve the US central bank's independence. Facing recession threats, he could announce an interest rate cut on the week of September 15, a move that Donald Trump has demanded for months.
byline: By Nicolas Chapuis (New York (United States) correspondent)

title: An abbey in southern France rescued by contemporary art
subhead: 'Strange places for an exhibition' (6/6). Le Monde explores six art centers set up in unusual locations. Today: a magnificent Cistercian abbey rescued from ruin by Geneviève Bonnefoi and Pierre Brache.

title: The Bayeux Tapestry, a barometer of Franco-British relations
subhead: France's decision to lend the nearly 1,000-year-old tapestry to the United Kingdom represents part of the long and tumultuous relationship between the two countries; Brexit supporters had even turned the tapestry into a symbol of national humiliation.

title: The Paris district where Parisians are priced out
subhead: In 50 years, the 8th arrondissement of the French capital, home to the Champs-Elysées and the 'Golden Triangle,' has lost nearly half its population. The mass acquisition of real estate by ultra-wealthy foreigners has driven locals out.
byline: By Véronique Chocron and Manon Romain

title: 'Monopoly capitalism in the US leads to underinvestment and to the concentration of wealth'
subhead: By analyzing the evolution of capitalism in the US since the 1960s, economist Patrick Artus argues that redistributive capitalism is the most effective, contrary to current practices.

title: Undercover but never unmasked: The untold story of a KGB spy in France
subhead: Following archival research and interviews with witnesses, Le Monde pieced together the completely unknown story of 'Lydia Tows,' a Russian agent who died in Paris in 1999. Working in tandem with a French police officer, she carried out a decades-long infiltration mission with devastating consequences.
